text: {{Infobox settlement | name = Okinawa Prefecture | native_name = 沖縄県 | native_name_lang = ja | settlement_type = Prefecture | translit_lang1 = Native | translit_lang1_type1 = Japanese | translit_lang1_info1 = | translit_lang1_type2 = Okinawan | translit_lang1_info2 = | image_flag = Flag of Okinawa Prefecture.svg | flag_size = 100px | image_blank_emblem = Emblem of Okinawa Prefecture.svg | blank_emblem_size = 80px | blank_emblem_type = Symbol | image_map = File:Map of Japan with 47 Okinawa prefecture.svg | coordinates = | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = | subdivision_type1 = Region | subdivision_name1 = Kyushu | subdivision_type2 = Island | subdivision_name2 = Okinawa, Daitō, Sakishima and Senkaku (disputed) | seat_type = Capital | seat = Naha | parts_type = Subdivisions | parts_style = para | p1 = Districts: 5 | p2 = Municipalities: 41 | leader_title = Governor | leader_name = Denny Tamaki | area_total_km2 = 2281 | area_water_percent = 0.5 | area_rank = 44th | population_footnotes = | population_total = 1457162 | population_as_of = February 2, 2020 | population_rank = 29th | population_density_km2 = auto | iso_code = JP-47 | website = | module = | official_name = }} is traditionally a prefecture in the Kyūshū region of Japan.Kanno, Eiji. (1998). New Japan Solo, p. 397; excerpt, "Administratively, Okinawa is part of Kyushu Region, even though it is l .000 km (625 miles) southwest of Kagoshima." Okinawa Prefecture is made up of islands which are southwest of the island of Kyushu.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Okinawa-ken" in Japan Encyclopedia, pp. 746-747. Recent government proposals recognize the prefecture as its own region.Hook, Glenn D. (2011). Decoding Boundaries in Contemporary Japan: The Koizumi Administration and Beyond, pp. 145-146. The capital city is Naha which is on the island of Okinawa.Nussbaum, "Naha" at p. 686. ==History== ===Timeline=== * 1429: Shō Hashi founded the Ryūkyū Kingdom * 1609: Shimazu of Satsuma Province invade Ryukyu Kingdom * 1853: Commodore Mathew Perry and US Navy ships at Naha * 1875 (Meiji 5): Ryūkyū Domain is created * 1879 (Meiji 12): Okinawa Prefecture was established. * 1945 (Shōwa 20): US administration after World War IINussbaum, "Ryukyu Islands" at p. 801. * 1953 (Shōwa 28): Partial reversion to Japan * 1972 (Shōwa 47): Reversion to Japan * 2000 (Heisei 12): 26th G8 summit at Kyushu and OkinawaJapan, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA): 26th G8 summit, overview. ==Geography== Okinawa is a grouping of many islands along the border at the edge of the East China Sea and the Pacific Ocean from Kyūshū to Taiwan. It is the southernmost prefecture in Japan. ===Cities=== Okinawa Prefecture has eleven cities. Okinawan names are in parentheses. * Ginowan (Jinoon) * Ishigaki (Ishigachi) * Itoman (Ichuman) * Miyakojima (Naaku) * Nago (Nagu) * Naha (Naafa) (capital) * Nanjō (Nanjoo) * Okinawa (Uchinaa) (formerly Koza) * Tomigusuku (Timigushiku) * Urasoe (Urashii) * Uruma (Uruma) ===Towns and villages=== These are the towns and villages in each district. * Kunigami District (Kunjan) **Ginoza (Jinuja) **Higashi (Agarijima) **Ie (Iijima) **Kin (Chin) **Kunigami (Kunjan) **Motobu (Mutubu) **Nakijin (Nachijin) **Onna (Unna) **Ōgimi (Ujimi) * Miyako District (Naaku) **Tarama (Tarama) * Nakagami District (Nakajan) **Chatan (Chatan) **Kadena (Kadina) **Kitanakagusuku **Nakagusuku (Nakagushiku) **Nishihara (Nishibaru) **Yomitan (Yuntan) * Shimajiri District (Shimajiri) **Aguni (Aguni) **Haebaru (Feebaru) **Iheya (Ihyaa) **Izena (Ijina) **Kitadaitō (Ufuagarijima) **Kumejima (Kumijima) **Minamidaitō **Tokashiki (Tukashichi) **Tonaki (Tunachi) **Yaese **Yonabaru (Yunabaru) **Zamami (Jamami) * Yaeyama District (Eema) **Taketomi (Dakidun) **Yonaguni (Yunaguni) ===National Parks=== National Parks are established in about 19% of the total land area of the prefecture.Japan Ministry of the Environment, "General overview of area figures for Natural Parks by prefecture". Retrieved 2012-3-13. ==Shrines and Temples== Naminouegū was the chief Shinto shrine (ichinomiya) of the Ryukyu Islands.Ponsonby-Fane, Richard. (1959). The Imperial House of Japan, p. 127. In 1890, the shrine was recognized in the system of State Shinto. It is among the ranked, nationally significant shrines or which includes five sanctuaries. List of Kankokuheisha (官国幣社), p. 3 . Retrieved 2012-8-26. ==Related pages== * Provinces of Japan * Prefectures of Japan * List of regions of Japan * List of islands of Japan ==References== ==More reading== * Kerr, George H. (1958). Okinawa: the History of an Island People. Rutland, Vermont: Charles Tuttle Co. OCLC 722356 * ___________. (1953). Ryukyu Kingdom and Province before 1945. Washington, D.C.: National Academy of Sciences, National Research Council.
